metadata.title: Run control scripts' executable search paths must contain only absolute paths.
metadata.description: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.

criteria.comment: Run control scripts' executable search paths

criterion.comment: run control scripts default search path ok (/etc/rc*/*)
run control scripts default search path ok (/etc/init.d)
run control scripts default search path ok (/lib/svc/method)
run control scripts default search path ok (/etc/rc*)

metadata.title: The TFTP daemon must operate in "secure mode" which provides access only to a single directory on the host file system.
metadata.description: Secure mode limits TFTP requests to a specific directory. If TFTP is not running in secure mode, it may be able to write to any file or directory and may seriously impair system integrity, confidentiality, and availability.

criteria.comment: TFTP daemon must operate in secure mode (-s)

criterion.comment: Determine if TFTPD is running in secure mode (-s) in /etc/inet/inetd.conf
Determine if TFTPD is running in secure mode (-s) in SMF

metadata.title: The /etc/shadow (or equivalent) file must have mode 0400.
metadata.description: The /etc/shadow file contains the list of local system accounts. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification. The file also contains password hashes which must not be accessible to users other than root.

criteria.comment: Verify mode on /etc/shadow is 0400

metadata.title: The inetd.conf and xinetd.conf files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/inetd.conf is 640 or less permissive

metadata.title: The system must not have the finger service active.
metadata.description: The finger service provides information about the system's users to network clients. This information could expose information that could be used in subsequent attacks.

criteria.comment: finger is not installed or disabled

criterion.comment: package with finger command is not installed

metadata.title: The system must not run an Internet Network News (INN) server.
metadata.description:
Internet Network News (INN) servers access Usenet newsfeeds and store newsgroup articles. INN servers use the Network News Transfer Protocol (NNTP) to transfer information from the Usenet to the server and from the server to authorized remote hosts.
If this function is necessary to support a valid mission requirement, its use must be authorized and approved in the system accreditation package.

criterion.comment: There are no innd or nntpd processes running.

metadata.title: The /etc/smb.conf file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If the smb.conf file has excessive permissions, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.

metadata.title: The /etc/smb.conf file must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
metadata.description: If the group-owner of the smb.conf file is not root or a system group, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.

metadata.title: The /etc/smb.conf file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: The /etc/smb.conf file allows access to other machines on the network and grants permissions to certain users. If it is owned by another user, the file may be maliciously modified and the Samba configuration could be compromised.

metadata.title: The system must not permit root logins using remote access programs such as ssh.
metadata.description: Even though communications are encrypted, an additional layer of security may be gained by extending the policy of not logging directly on as root. In addition, logging in with a user-specific account preserves the audit trail.

criteria.comment: The system must not permit root logins using remote access programs such as ssh.

criterion.comment: Testing to ensure PermitRootLogin option is set to "no" within the ssh.config file.

metadata.title: Audio devices must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Audio and video devices that are globally accessible have proven to be another security hazard. There is software that can activate system microphones and video devices connected to user workstations and/or X terminals. Once the microphone has been activated, it is possible to eavesdrop on otherwise private conversations without the victim being aware of it. This action effectively changes the user's microphone to a bugging device.

criteria.comment: Audio devices must be owned by root.

metadata.title: Audio devices must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
metadata.description: Without privileged group owners, audio devices will be vulnerable to being used as eaves-dropping devices by malicious users or intruders to possibly listen to conversations containing sensitive information.

criteria.comment: Audio devices must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.

criterion.comment: /etc/audio must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys

metadata.title: The /etc/smbpasswd file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If the smbpasswd file has a mode more permissive than 0600, the smbpasswd file may be maliciously accessed or modified, potentially resulting in the compromise of Samba accounts.

metadata.title: All global initialization files' executable search paths must contain only absolute paths.
metadata.description: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon, or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Paths starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.

criterion.comment: Verify any path found contains only absolute paths
search global init files for PATH statements
Verify any path found contains only absolute paths

metadata.title: There must be no .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, or shosts.equiv files on the system.
metadata.description: The .rhosts, .shosts, hosts.equiv, and shosts.equiv files are used to configure host-based authentication for individual users or the system. Host-based authentication is not sufficient for preventing unauthorized access to the system.

criterion.comment: There are no .rhosts or .shosts files in home directories.

metadata.title: The .rhosts file must not be supported in PAM.
metadata.description: .rhosts files are used to specify a list of hosts that are permitted remote access to a particular account without authenticating. The use of such a mechanism defeats strong identification and authentication requirements.

metadata.title: The system must implement non-executable program stacks.
metadata.description: A common type of exploit is the stack buffer overflow. An application receives, from an attacker, more data than it is prepared for and stores this information on its stack, writing beyond the space reserved for it. This can be designed to cause execution of the data written on the stack. One mechanism to mitigate this vulnerability is for the system to not allow the execution of instructions in sections of memory identified as part of the stack.

criteria.comment: The system must implement non-executable program stacks.

metadata.title: The system must use initial TCP sequence numbers most resistant to sequence number guessing attacks.
metadata.description: One use of initial TCP sequence numbers is to verify bidirectional communication between two hosts, which provides some protection against spoofed source addresses being used by the connection originator. If the initial TCP sequence numbers for a host can be determined by an attacker, it may be possible to establish a TCP connection from a spoofed source address without bidirectional communication.

criteria.comment: The system must use initial TCP sequence numbers most resistant to sequence number guessing attacks.

metadata.title: A separate file system must be used for user home directories (such as /home or equivalent).
metadata.description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.

criteria.comment: A separate file system must be used for user home directories

metadata.title: All .Xauthority files must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: .Xauthority files ensure that the user is authorized to access that specific X Windows host. Excessive permissions may permit unauthorized modification of these files, which could lead to denial of service to authorized access or allow unauthorized access to be obtained.

criteria.comment: All .Xauthority files must have mode 0600 or less permissive

criterion.comment: .Xauthority files must have mode 0600 or less permissive

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering.
metadata.description: The SSH daemon must be configured for IP filtering to provide a layered defense against connection attempts from unauthorized addresses.

criterion.comment: Access to sshd is checked against TCP Wrappers

metadata.title: The system's access control program must be configured to grant or deny system access to specific hosts.
metadata.description: If the system's access control program is not configured with appropriate rules for allowing and denying access to system network resources, services may be accessible to unauthorized hosts.

metadata.title: The nosuid option must be configured in the /etc/rmmount.conf file.
metadata.description: The rmmount.conf file controls the mounting of removable media on a Solaris system. Removable media are not to be trusted with privileged access, and therefore the filesystems must be mounted with the nosuid option, which prevents any executables with the setuid bit set on this filesystem from running with owner privileges.

metadata.title: The root account must be the only account with GID of 0.
metadata.description: This is applicable to Solaris 10, and later. Accounts with a GID of 0 have root group privileges.

criteria.comment: The root account must be the only account with GID of 0.

criterion.comment: The root account must be the only account with GID of 0.
The root group must be the only group with GID of 0.

metadata.title: The system clock must be synchronized continuously, or at least daily.
metadata.description:
A synchronized system clock is critical for the enforcement of time-based policies and the correlation of logs and audit records with other systems. Internal system clocks tend to drift and require periodic resynchronization to ensure their accuracy. Software, such as ntpd, can be used to continuously synchronize the system clock with authoritative sources. Alternatively, the system may be synchronized periodically, with a maximum of one day between synchronizations.
If the system is completely isolated (that is, it has no connections to networks or other systems), time synchronization is not required as no correlation of events or operation of time-dependent protocols between systems will be necessary. If the system is completely isolated, this requirement is not applicable.

criterion.comment: ntpdate is invoked by cron at least daily

metadata.title: The password hashes stored on the system must have been generated using a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm.
metadata.description: Systems must employ cryptographic hashes for passwords using the SHA-2 family of algorithms or FIPS 140-2 approved successors. The use of unapproved algorithms may result in weak password hashes that are more vulnerable to compromise.

criteria.comment: The password hashes stored on the system must have been generated using a FIPS 140-2 approved cryptographic hashing algorithm.

criterion.comment: FIPS 140-2 approved hashes are available for use

metadata.title: The system must require at least four characters be changed between the old and new passwords during a password change.
metadata.description: To ensure that password changes are effective in their goals, the system must ensure that old and new passwords have significant differences. Without significant changes, new passwords may be easily guessed based on the value of a previously compromised password.

criteria.comment: verify the MINDIFF setting

metadata.title: The /etc/passwd file must not contain password hashes.
metadata.description: If password hashes are readable by non-administrators, the passwords are subject to attack through lookup tables or cryptographic weaknesses in the hashes.

criteria.comment: The /etc/passwd file must not contain password hashes.

criterion.comment: Verify all users have password field of x

metadata.title: The /etc/group file must not contain any group password hashes.
metadata.description: Group passwords are typically shared and should not be used. Additionally, if password hashes are readable by non-administrators, the passwords are subject to attack through lookup tables or cryptographic weaknesses in the hashes.

criteria.comment: Check the /etc/group file for password hashes

criterion.comment: Check the /etc/group file for password hashes

metadata.title: System audit tool executables must be owned by root.
metadata.description: To prevent unauthorized access or manipulation of system audit logs, the tools for manipulating those logs must be protected.

criteria.comment: System audit tool executables must be owned by root.

metadata.title: System audit tool executables must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.
metadata.description: To prevent unauthorized access or manipulation of system audit logs, the tools for manipulating those logs must be protected.

criteria.comment: System audit tool executables must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys.

metadata.title: System audit tool executables must have mode 0750 or less permissive.
metadata.description: To prevent unauthorized access or manipulation of system audit logs, the tools for manipulating those logs must be protected.

criteria.comment: System audit tool executables must have mode 0750 or less permissive.

metadata.title: The audit system must be configured to audit the loading and unloading of dynamic kernel modules.
metadata.description: Actions concerning dynamic kernel modules must be recorded as they are substantial events. Dynamic kernel modules can increase the attack surface of a system. A malicious kernel module can be used to substantially alter the functioning of a system, often with the purpose of hiding a compromise from the SA.

criteria.comment: flags must contain as
flags contain as
or flags contain +as and -as
there are no flag resets

metadata.title: The system must prevent local applications from generating source-routed packets.
metadata.description: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures.

criteria.comment: The system must prevent local applications from generating source-routed packets.

metadata.title: The system must not accept source-routed IPv4 packets.
metadata.description: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the handling of source-routed traffic destined to the system itself, not to traffic forwarded by the system to another, such as when IPv4 forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.

criteria.comment: The system must not accept source-routed IPv4 packets.

metadata.title: The portmap or rpcbind service must not be running unless needed.
metadata.description: The portmap and rpcbind services increase the attack surface of the system and should only be used when needed. The portmap or rpcbind services are used by a variety of services using remote procedure calls (RPCs).

metadata.title: The rexecd service must not be installed.
metadata.description: The rexecd process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service. SSH should be used in place of this service.

metadata.title: The rlogind service must not be installed.
metadata.description: The rlogind process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service. SSH should be used in place of this service.

metadata.title: The rshd service must not be installed.
metadata.description: The rshd process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service. SSH should be used in place of this service.

metadata.title: The rlogind service must not be running.
metadata.description: The rlogind process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service. SSH should be used in place of this service.

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.
metadata.description: SSHv1 is not a DoD-approved protocol and has many well-known vulnerability exploits. Exploits of the SSH client could provide access to the system with the privileges of the user running the client.

criteria.comment: The SSH client must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must be configured to not use Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) ciphers.
metadata.description: The Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen plain text attacks and must not be used.

criteria.comment: SSH daemon must be configured to not use CBC ciphers

criterion.comment: Check for Cipher keyword in file

metadata.title: The SSH client must be configured to not use Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) ciphers.
metadata.description: The Cipher-Block Chaining (CBC) mode of encryption as implemented in the SSHv2 protocol is vulnerable to chosen plain text attacks and must not be used.

criteria.comment: SSH client must be configured to not use CBC ciphers

criterion.comment: Check for Cipher keyword in file

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system?s GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.

criteria.comment: The SSH daemon must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.

metadata.title: The SSH client must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.
metadata.description: GSSAPI authentication is used to provide additional authentication mechanisms to applications. Allowing GSSAPI authentication through SSH exposes the system?s GSSAPI to remote hosts, increasing the attack surface of the system. GSSAPI authentication must be disabled unless needed.

criteria.comment: The SSH client must not permit GSSAPI authentication unless needed.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must not allow compression or must only allow compression after successful authentication.
metadata.description: If compression is allowed in an SSH connection prior to authentication, vulnerabilities in the compression software could result in compromise of the system from an unauthenticated connection, potentially with root privileges.

criteria.comment: The SSH daemon must not allow compression or must only allow compression after successful authentication.

criterion.comment: Check "Compression" is set to "no" or "delay" in /etc/ssh/sshd_config.
Check "Compression" is set to "no" or "delay" in /etc/ssh/sshd_config.

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must be configured with the Department of Defense (DoD) login banner.
metadata.description:
Failure to display the DoD logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.
The SSH service must be configured to display the DoD logon warning banner either through the SSH configuration or a wrapper program such as TCP_WRAPPERS.
The SSH daemon may also be used to provide SFTP service. The warning banner configuration for SSH will apply to SFTP.

criterion.comment: DoD Login Banner is configured for sshd

metadata.title: Samba must be configured to use an authentication mechanism other than share.
metadata.description: Samba share authentication does not provide for individual user identification and must not be used.

criteria.comment: Samba security parameter must not be share

metadata.title: Samba must be configured to not allow guest access to shares.
metadata.description: Guest access to shares permits anonymous access and is not permitted.

criteria.comment: guest access to shares must not be allowed

criterion.comment: test for guest ok share access

metadata.title: The DHCP client must be disabled if not needed.
metadata.description: DHCP allows for the unauthenticated configuration of network parameters on the system by exchanging information with a DHCP server.

metadata.title: Automated file system mounting tools must not be enabled unless needed.
metadata.description: Automated file system mounting tools may provide unprivileged users with the ability to access local media and network shares. If this access is not necessary for the systemâ€™s operation, it must be disabled to reduce the risk of unauthorized access to these resources.

metadata.title: The system must have USB disabled unless needed.
metadata.description: USB is a common computer peripheral interface. USB devices may include storage devices that could be used to install malicious software on a system or exfiltrate data.

metadata.title: The system must employ a local firewall.
metadata.description: A local firewall protects the system from exposing unnecessary or undocumented network services to the local enclave. If a system within the enclave is compromised, firewall protection on an individual system continues to protect it from attack.

metadata.title: The system package management tool must cryptographically verify the authenticity of software packages during installation.
metadata.description: To prevent the installation of software from unauthorized sources, the system package management tool must use cryptographic algorithms to verify the packages are authentic.

metadata.title: The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be group-owned by sys.
metadata.description: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.

criteria.comment: The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be group-owned by sys.

criterion.comment: /etc/zones directory must be group-owned by sys.
/etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be group-owned by sys.

metadata.title: The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.

criteria.comment: The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be owned by root.

metadata.title: The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Solaris zones configuration files must be protected against illicit creation, modification, and deletion.

criteria.comment: The /etc/zones directory, and its contents, must have mode 0755 or less permissive.

metadata.title: The system must use a separate file system for /tmp (or equivalent).
metadata.description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.

criteria.comment: The system must use a separate file system for /tmp

metadata.title: The telnet daemon must not be running.
metadata.description: The telnet daemon provides a typically unencrypted remote access service which does not provide for the confidentiality and integrity of user passwords or the remote session. If a privileged user were to log on using this service, the privileged user password could be compromised.

metadata.title: The system must prohibit the reuse of passwords within five iterations.
metadata.description: If a user, or root, used the same password continuously or was allowed to change it back shortly after being forced to change it to something else, it would provide a potential intruder with the opportunity to keep guessing at one user's password until it was guessed correctly.

criteria.comment: /etc/default/passwd HISTORY setting

metadata.title: All system start-up files must be owned by root.
metadata.description: System start-up files not owned by root could lead to system compromise by allowing malicious users or applications to modify them for unauthorized purposes. This could lead to system and network compromise.

criteria.comment: All system start-up files must be owned by root

criterion.comment: All system start-up files must be owned by root or bin

metadata.title: All system start-up files must be group-owned by root, sys, bin, or other.
metadata.description: If system start-up files do not have a group owner of root or a system group, the files may be modified by malicious users or intruders.

criteria.comment: All system start-up files must be group-owned by root, sys, bin or other

criterion.comment: System start-up files must be group-owned by root, sys, bin, or other

metadata.title: The SSH daemon must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.
metadata.description: SSHv1 is not a DoD-approved protocol and has many well-known vulnerability exploits. Exploits of the SSH daemon could provide immediate root access to the system.

criteria.comment: The SSH daemon must be configured to only use the SSHv2 protocol.

metadata.title: The NFS server must have logging implemented.
metadata.description: File System logging, especially for NFS exported file systems, can be critical to detecting data misuse and possible hardware/system errors that may, otherwise, go unnoticed.

criteria.comment: The NFS server must has logging implemented.

criterion.comment: The NFS server must has logging implemented.

metadata.title: The root file system must employ journaling or another mechanism that ensures file system consistency.
metadata.description: File system journaling, or logging, can allow reconstruction of file system data after a system crash, thus, preserving the integrity of data that may have otherwise been lost. Journaling file systems typically do not require consistency checks upon booting after a crash, which can improve system availability. Some file systems employ other mechanisms to ensure consistency which also satisfy this requirement.

criteria.comment: Root file system must emply journaling or another mechanism to ensure file system consistency

metadata.title: The system must not run Samba unless needed.
metadata.description: Samba is a tool used for the sharing of files and printers between Windows and UNIX operating systems. It provides access to sensitive files and, therefore, poses a security risk if compromised.

metadata.title: The traceroute command owner must be root.
metadata.description: If the traceroute command owner has not been set to root, an unauthorized user could use this command to obtain knowledge of the network topology inside the firewall. This information may allow an attacker to determine trusted routers and other network information that may lead to system and network compromise.

criteria.comment: The traceroute command ownership

metadata.title: Anonymous FTP accounts must not have a functional shell.
metadata.description: If an anonymous FTP account has been configured to use a functional shell, attackers could gain access to the shell if the account is compromised.

criteria.comment: FTP accounts must not have functional shell

metadata.title: The rsh daemon must not be running.
metadata.description: The rshd process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service. SSH should be used in place of this service.

metadata.title: The rexec daemon must not be running.
metadata.description: The rexec process provides a typically unencrypted, host-authenticated remote access service. SSH should be used in place of this service.

metadata.title: The Department of Defense (DoD) login banner must be displayed immediately prior to, or as part of, console login prompts.
metadata.description: Failure to display the logon banner prior to a logon attempt will negate legal proceedings resulting from unauthorized access to system resources.

metadata.title: The system must disable accounts after three consecutive unsuccessful login attempts.
metadata.description: Disabling accounts after a limited number of unsuccessful login attempts improves protection against password guessing attacks.

criteria.comment: The system must disable accounts after three consecutive unsuccessful login attempts.

metadata.title: The delay between login prompts following a failed login attempt must be at least 4 seconds.
metadata.description: Enforcing a delay between successive failed login attempts increases protection against automated password guessing attacks.

criteria.comment: The delay between login prompts following a failed login attempt must be at least 4 seconds.

metadata.title: The root account must be the only account having a UID of 0.
metadata.description: If an account has a UID of 0, it has root authority. Multiple accounts with a UID of 0 afford more opportunity for potential intruders to guess a password for a privileged account.

criteria.comment: The root account must be the only account having a UID of 0.

metadata.title: The root user's home directory must not be the root directory (/).
metadata.description: Changing the root home directory to something other than / and assigning it a 0700 protection makes it more difficult for intruders to manipulate the system by reading the files that root places in its default directory. It also gives root the same discretionary access control for root's home directory as for the other plain user home directories.

criteria.comment: The root user's home directory must not be the root directory (/).

metadata.title: The root account's home directory (other than /) must have mode 0700.
metadata.description: Permissions greater than 0700 could allow unauthorized users access to the root home directory.

criteria.comment: Root Account's Home Directory

metadata.title: The root account's executable search path must be the vendor default and must contain only absolute paths.
metadata.description: The executable search path (typically the PATH environment variable) contains a list of directories for the shell to search to find executables. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, executables in these directories may be executed instead of system commands. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Entries starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.

criteria.comment: root account executable search path

metadata.title: The root account's library search path must be the system default and must contain only absolute paths.
metadata.description: The library search path environment variable(s) contain a list of directories for the dynamic linker to search to find libraries. If this path includes the current working directory or other relative paths, libraries in these directories may be loaded instead of system libraries. This variable is formatted as a colon-separated list of directories. If there is an empty entry, such as a leading or trailing colon or two consecutive colons, this is interpreted as the current working directory. Entries starting with a slash (/) are absolute paths.

criteria.comment: root account's library search path

metadata.title: The root account's list of preloaded libraries must be empty.
metadata.description: The library preload list environment variable contains a list of libraries for the dynamic linker to load before loading the libraries required by the binary. If this list contains paths to libraries relative to the current working directory, unintended libraries may be preloaded. This variable is formatted as a space-separated list of libraries. Paths starting with (/) are absolute paths.

criteria.comment: root account's list of preloaded libraries

metadata.title: The system must prevent the root account from directly logging in except from the system console.
metadata.description: Limiting the root account direct logins to only system consoles protects the root account from direct unauthorized access from a non-console device.

criteria.comment: The system must prevent the root account from directly logging in except from the system console.

criterion.comment: Limit the root account direct logins to only system consoles

metadata.title: All GIDs referenced in the /etc/passwd file must be defined in the /etc/group file.
metadata.description: If a user is assigned the GID of a group that does not exist on the system, and a group with that GID is subsequently created, the user may have unintended rights to that group.

criteria.comment: check for that all referenced GIDs exist

metadata.title: System log files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If the system log files are not protected, unauthorized users could change the logged data, eliminating its forensic value.

criteria.comment: System log files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.

metadata.title: All skeleton files (typically those in /etc/skel) must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files.

criteria.comment: All skeleton files (typically those in /etc/skel) must have mode 0644 or less permissive.

criterion.comment: All skeleton files have mode 0644 or less permissive

metadata.title: All skeleton files and directories (typically in /etc/skel) must be owned by root or bin.
metadata.description: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.

criteria.comment: All skeleton files and directories (typically in /etc/skel) must be owned by root or bin.

criterion.comment: All skeleton files must be owned by root or bin

metadata.title: All skeleton files (typically in /etc/skel) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, system, or other.
metadata.description: If the skeleton files are not protected, unauthorized personnel could change user startup parameters and possibly jeopardize user files.

criteria.comment: All skeleton files (typically in /etc/skel) must be group-owned by root, bin, sys, system, or other.

criterion.comment: All skeleton files must be group owned by root, bin, sys or other

metadata.title: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be group-owned by root, sys, bin.
metadata.description: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are, therefore, critical to system security. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.

criteria.comment: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be group-owned by root, sys, bin.

criterion.comment: Files are to be group-owned by root, sys, bin.
Files are to be group-owned by root, sys, bin.

metadata.title: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be owned by root, sys, or bin.
metadata.description: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are, therefore, critical to system security. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.

criteria.comment: NIS/NIS+/yp files must be owned by root, sys, or bin.

criterion.comment: Files must be owned by root, sys, or bin
Files must be owned by root, sys, or bin

metadata.title: The NIS/NIS+/yp command files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
metadata.description: NIS/NIS+/yp files are part of the system's identification and authentication processes and are, therefore, critical to system security. Unauthorized modification of these files could compromise these processes and the system.

criteria.comment: The NIS/NIS+/yp command files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.

criterion.comment: Files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
Files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.

metadata.title: Library files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Unauthorized access could destroy the integrity of the library files.

criteria.comment: Library files must have mode 0755 or less permissive.

metadata.title: System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group.
metadata.description: Restricting permissions will protect the files from unauthorized modification.

criteria.comment: System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group.

criterion.comment: System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group (/etc)
System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group (/bin)
System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group (/usr/bin)
System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group (/usr/lbin)
System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group (/usr/usb)
System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group (/sbin)
System files, programs, and directories must be group-owned by a system group (/usr/sbin)

metadata.title: The /etc/shadow (or equivalent) file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: The /etc/shadow file contains the list of local system accounts. It is vital to system security and must be protected from unauthorized modification. Failure to give ownership of sensitive files or utilities to root or bin provides the designated owner and unauthorized users with the potential to access sensitive information or change the system configuration which could weaken the system's security posture.

criteria.comment: Verify root owns /etc/shadow

metadata.title: Auditing must be implemented
metadata.description: Without auditing, individual system accesses cannot be tracked and malicious activity cannot be detected and traced back to an individual account.

criteria.comment: Auditing must be implemented

metadata.title: All system audit logs files must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: If a user can write to the audit logs, audit trails can be modified or destroyed and system intrusion may not be detected. System audit logs are those files generated from the audit system and do not include activity, error, or other log files created by application software.

criteria.comment: All shells must have a mode within a specified range.

criterion.comment: The audit log directory must have mode 0750 or less permissive.
System audit logs must have mode 0640 or less permissive.

metadata.title: System audit logs must be group owned by root,bin or sys.
metadata.description: System audit log files with world/group write permissions give the ability to maliciously modify log records to cover unauthorized access.

criteria.comment: System audit logs must be group owned by root,bin or sys.

criterion.comment: The audit log directory must be group owned by root, bin or sys.
System audit logs must be group owned by root, bin or sys.

metadata.title: The audit logs (including the directory) must be owned by root.
metadata.description: The audit log directory defined in /etc/security/audit_control nor the log files in it may be modifiable by regular users.

criteria.comment: audit log dir is protected

criterion.comment: The audit log directory must be owned by root
System audit logs must be owned by root

metadata.title: The audit system must be configured to audit failed attempts to access files and programs.
metadata.description: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.

criteria.comment: fr, -fr, all or -all must present in flags

criterion.comment: fr or -fr or all or -all present

criteria.comment: there are no flag resets

criterion.comment: test for no flag fr resets
test for no flag all resets

metadata.title: The audit system must be configured to audit file deletions.
metadata.description: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.

criteria.comment: flags must both contain
flags contain fd or all
or flags contains both +fd and -fd
there are no flag resets

metadata.title: The audit system must be configured to audit login, logout, and session initiation.
metadata.description: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.

criteria.comment: flags and naflags must both contain
flags contain am or all
or flags contains both +am and -am
there are no flag resets

metadata.title: The audit system must be configured to audit login, logout, and session initiation.
metadata.description: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.

criteria.comment: flags and naflags must both contain
flags contain lo or all
or flags contains both +lo and -lo
naflags contain lo or all

criterion.comment: naflag test for lo or all

criteria.comment: or naflags contain both +lo and -lo
there are no flag resets
there are no naflag resets

metadata.title: The audit system must be configured to audit all discretionary access control permission modifications.
metadata.description: If the system is not configured to audit certain activities and write them to an audit log, it is more difficult to detect and track system compromises and damages incurred during a system compromise.

criteria.comment: flags and naflags must both contain
flags contain fm or all
or flags contains both +fm and -fm
there are no flag resets

metadata.title: Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands.
metadata.description: If the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" command is not placed into the system profile, messaging can be used to cause a denial of service attack.

criteria.comment: Global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands.

criterion.comment: Check global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands in (/etc/login)
Check global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands (/etc/profile)
Check global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands (/etc/bashrc)
Check global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands (/etc/environment)
Check global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands (/etc/security/environ)
Check global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands in (/etc/csh.login)
Check global initialization files must contain the "mesg -n" or "mesg n" commands in (/etc/csh.cshrc)

metadata.title: Sendmail logging must not be set to less than nine in the sendmail.cf file.
metadata.description: If Sendmail is not configured to log at level 9, system logs may not contain the information necessary for tracking unauthorized use of the sendmail service.

criteria.comment: loglevel test

metadata.title: The system syslog service must log informational and more severe SMTP service messages.
metadata.description: If informational and more severe SMTP service messages are not logged, malicious activity on the system may go unnoticed.

criteria.comment: mail.crit must be logged

metadata.title: The ftpusers file must exist.
metadata.description: The ftpusers file contains a list of accounts that are not allowed to use FTP to transfer files. If this file does not exist, then unauthorized accounts can utilize FTP.

criteria.comment: The ftpusers file must exist.

metadata.title: The Network Information System (NIS) protocol must not be used.
metadata.description: Due to numerous security vulnerabilities that exist within NIS, it must not be used. Possible alternative directory services are NIS+ and LDAP.

criterion.comment: There are no ypbind or ypserv processes running.

metadata.title: All interactive users must be assigned a home directory in the /etc/passwd file.
metadata.description: If users do not have a valid home directory, there is no place for the storage and control of files they own.

criteria.comment: Verify all users have a home directory

criterion.comment: Verify all users have a home directory

metadata.title: All interactive user home directories defined in the /etc/passwd file must exist.
metadata.description: If a user has a home directory defined that does not exist, the user may be given the / directory, by default, as the current working directory upon logon. This could create a denial of service because the user would not be able to perform useful tasks in this location.

criteria.comment: Verify all user home directories exist

criterion.comment: Verify all user home directories exist

metadata.title: The /etc/shells (or equivalent) file must exist.
metadata.description: The shells file (or equivalent) lists approved default shells. It helps provide layered defense to the security approach by ensuring users cannot change their default shell to an unauthorized shell that may not be secure.

criteria.comment: The /etc/shells (or equivalent) file must exist.

metadata.title: The /usr/aset/userlist file must exist.
metadata.description: If the userlist file does not exist, then an unauthorized user may exist in the /etc/passwd file.

criteria.comment: /usr/aset/userlist file exists

metadata.title: Access to the cron utility must be controlled using the cron.allow and/or cron.deny file(s).
metadata.description: The cron facility allows users to execute recurring jobs on a regular and unattended basis. The cron.allow file designates accounts that are allowed to enter and execute jobs using the cron facility. If neither cron.allow nor cron.deny exists, then any account may use the cron facility. That may open the facility up for abuse by system intruders and malicious users.

criteria.comment: Access to the cron utility must be controlled using the cron.allow and/or cron.deny file(s).

metadata.title: The cronlog file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Cron logs contain reports of scheduled system activities and must be protected from unauthorized access or manipulation.

criteria.comment: The cronlog file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.

criterion.comment: Check /var/cron/log has mode 0600 or less permissive

metadata.title: Access to the "at" utility must be controlled via the at.allow and/or at.deny file(s).
metadata.description: The "at" facility selectively allows users to execute jobs at deferred times. It is usually used for one-time jobs. The at.allow file selectively allows access to the "at" facility. If there is no at.allow file, there is no ready documentation of who is allowed to submit "at" jobs.

criteria.comment: Access to the "at" utility must be controlled via the at.allow and/or at.deny file(s).

metadata.title: The at.deny file must not be empty if it exists.
metadata.description: On some systems, if there is no at.allow file and there is an empty at.deny file, then the system assumes that everyone has permission to use the "at" facility. This could create an insecure setting in the case of malicious users or system intruders.

criteria.comment: The at.deny file must not be empty if it exists.

metadata.title: The /etc/passwd file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/passwd is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The services file must be owned by root or bin.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criteria.comment: Test ownership of /etc/services

metadata.title: The services file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/services is 644 or less permissive

metadata.title: The alias file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The ftpusers file must have mode 0640 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/ftpd/ftpusers is 640 or less permissive

metadata.title: The NFS export configuration file must be owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The NFS export configuration file must have mode 0644 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/dfs/dfstab is 644 or less permissive

metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The /usr/aset/userlist file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /usr/aset/userlist is 600 or less permissive

metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/cron.d/cron.allow is 600 or less permissive

metadata.title: Crontab files must have mode 0600 or less permissive, and files in cron script directories must have mode 0700 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /var/spool/cron/crontabs/* is 600 or less permissive

metadata.title: Cron and crontab directories must have mode 0755 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /var/spool/cron/crontabs is 755 or less permissive

metadata.title: Cron and crontab directories must be owned by root or bin.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criteria.comment: Test ownership of /var/spool/cron/crontabs

metadata.title: Cron and crontab directories must be group-owned by root, sys, or bin.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.title: The at.allow file must have mode 0600 or less permissive.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/cron.d/at.allow is 600 or less permissive

metadata.title: The /etc/sfw/private/smbpasswd file must be group-owned by root.
metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/news/hosts.nntp is 600 or less permissive

metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

criterion.comment: Test mode of /etc/news/passwd.nntp is 600 or less permissive

metadata.description: Tests for compliance with the requirement.

textfilecontent54_test.comment: Determine if TFTPD is running in secure mode (-s) in /etc/inet/inetd.conf

independent-def:xmlfilecontent_test.comment: Determine if TFTPD is running in secure mode (-s) in SMF (via XML configuration file)

file_test.comment: Test mode of /etc/inetd.conf is 640 or less permissive

package_test.comment: package with finger command is installed

unix-def:process_test.comment: There are no innd or nntpd processes running.

textfilecontent54_test.comment: Testing to ensure PermitRootLogin option is set to "no" within the ssh.config file.

file_test.comment: /etc/audio must be group-owned by root, bin, or sys
/etc/audio must have mode 0660 or less permissive

variable_test.comment: Verify any path found contains only absolute paths
Verify any path found contains only absolute paths

textfilecontent54_test.comment: search global init files for PATH statements

unix-def:file_test.comment: There are no .rhosts or .shosts files in home directories.

file_test.comment: .Xauthority files must have mode 0600 or less permissive

ind-def:textfilecontent54_test.comment: Access to sshd is checked against TCP Wrappers

password_test.comment: The root account must be the only account with GID of 0.

textfilecontent54_test.comment: The root group must be the only group with GID of 0.

ind-def:textfilecontent54_test.comment: ntpdate is invoked by cron at least daily
FIPS 140-2 approved hashes are available for use

password_test.comment: Verify password field contains x indicating the use of the shadow file

textfilecontent54_test.comment: verify /etc/group password field contains nothing but x or ! or must start with a :

file_test.comment: /usr/sbin/auditconfig file must have mode of 0750 or less permissive
/usr/sbin/praudit file must have mode of 0750 or less permissive
/usr/sbin/auditreduce file must have mode of 0750 or less permissive
/usr/sbin/bsmrecord file must have mode of 0750 or less permissive

/usr/sbin/auditd file must be group-owned by root, sys or bin

/usr/sbin/praudit file must be owned by root
/usr/sbin/auditreduce file must be owned by root
/usr/sbin/bsmrecord file must be owned by root
/usr/sbin/audit file must be owned by root
/usr/sbin/auditd file must be owned by root

textfilecontent54_test.comment: Check /etc/ipf/ipf.conf "block in log quick all with opt ssrr"
Check /etc/ipf/ipf.conf "block in log quick all with opt lsrr"
Check /etc/ipf/ipf.conf "block out log quick all with opt ssrr"
Check /etc/ipf/ipf.conf "block out log quick all with opt lsrr"

Check for Cipher keyword in file
Check "Compression" is set to "no" or "delayed" in /etc/ssh/sshd_config.
Check "Compression" is set to "no" or "delayed" in /etc/ssh/sshd_config.

ind-def:textfilecontent54_test.comment: DoD Login Banner is configured for sshd

textfilecontent54_test.comment: verify the security parameter is not share
tests for guest ok = yes parameter

file_test.comment: /etc/zones and its contents must be owned by root.
/etc/zones directory must be owned by root.
/etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be group-owned by root, sys or bin.
/etc/zones directory, and its contents, must be group-owned by root, sys or bin.

textfilecontent54_test.comment: Determine if the /tmp path is a separate filesystem

file_test.comment: All system start-up files must be owned by root
System start-up files group-owned by root, sys, bin, or other

textfilecontent54_test.comment: The NFS server must has logging implemented.
